citation.article-title: Hydrogenivirga okinawensis sp. nov., a thermophilic sulfur-oxidizing chemolithoautotroph isolated from a deep-sea hydrothermal field, Southern Okinawa Trough.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Hydrogenivirga okinawensis sp. nov.
Hydrogenivirga okinawensis (o.ki.na′wen.sis. N.L. fem. adj. okinawensis of Okinawa, a region of Japan).
pH range for growth is 5.8–8.3 (optimum pH 6.9–7.5).
NaCl concentration range for growth is 1.0–4.0 % (optimum 2.5 %).
O2 concentration range for aerobic growth at 200 kPa is 1.0–7.0 % (optimum 2.0–3.0 %).
Obligate chemolithotrophic growth occurs with elemental sulfur and thiosulfate as electron donors and oxygen and nitrate as electron acceptors.
Nitrate is reduced to nitrogen and sulfur is oxidized to sulfate and thiosulfate.
Major cellular fatty acids are C16 : 0 (8.0 %), C18 : 0 (9.0 %), C18 : 1 (62.5 %) and C20 : 1 (20.5 %).
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 51.3 mol% (HPLC).
The 16S rRNA gene sequence similarity of the type strain to the type strain of Hydrogenivirga caldilitoris is 94.7 %.
The type strain is LS12-2T (=JCM 13302T=DSM 17378T), isolated from a sulfide chimney structure at the Yonaguni Knoll IV hydrothermal field along the Southern Okinawa Trough.
